Supplement #4. 1st quarter, 1957 offering
Voices of Europe (continued)
3
Program
12
13
Issue Topic and Speakers
12 the famous raconteur, the Baron von Munchausf
who raised the level of lying to the art of
literature, has lived in Florence almost as
much as he has in Germany. He joined the
Communists when he was 20 and left them for
the Nazis when he was 22. At the age of 24
he deserted the Nazis and returned to Flor¬
ence with his wife after the war.
13 A. "Weather” - Professor Doctor Friederich
Defant, authority on the Alps and world
famous meteorologist , has worked for the
U. S. Navy on weather and atmosphere
research. He has experimented and taught
at the University of Chicago, the University
of California at Los Angeles, and the
University of Innsbruck in Austria.
B. "Swiss Films" - Herr Lazar Wechsler,
Swiss film producer, was originally an
engineer. Originated multilingual film in
"The Last Chance," and has produced "The
Search," "Four in A Jeep," "Marie Louise,"
"He?di," and other fine films.
* x x x * x * ** x xxx x x x * x
Window on the World (56-54)
Program 13 (issue 4) - nAs I Saw the U.S.A." - James Morris, correspondent for the
London Times came to the United States to gather information
for his book "As I Saw the U.S.A." published in 1956. In
this talk he describes some of the things that impressed
and interested him in America.
Program 14 (issue 5) - "Challenge of the English Theatre" - Peter Ustinov, actor,
director, producer and playwright at 35 is well known for
his movie and theatre roles.
Program 15 (issue 6) - "Britain Puts the Atom to Work" - An interview with Sir
Edwin Plowden, Chairman of Britain's Atomic Energy Authority
concerning Calder Hall, the first atomic power station to
produce electricity commercially.
Program 16 (issue 7) - "What’s Best in American and British Movies" - Dilys Powell,
one of Britain’s most popular critics, writes about movies
for London’s Sunday Times. Newly arrived in the United
States she is off to Hollywood.
